issue.title: clarify shuffle docs
issue.body:
Fixes https://github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1258

In that issue @vks makes a remark about the generator state space. Is that something that should be mentioned here? I am not sure if I fully understand the remark, it seems to be about fundamental limits of finite-state pseudo-random number generators.

comment.body: Yes, it's about how many different numbers a PRNG with a finite seed / state can generate. It's explained a bit more [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle#Pseudorandom_generators).

issue.title: Is 'shuffle' uniform across all permutations?
issue.body: The documentation for `shuffle` does not explicitly state the probability distribution it implements. What I would expect as a result is a permutation chosen uniformly at random from the set of all permutations. Is that what it does?

comment.body: This also depends on the generator: If the number of permutations is larger than the state can represent, some permutations have zero probability.

issue.title: Statistics for data sets with 0 or 1 element
issue.body:
Currently, the following example

```rust
use average::{Estimate, Mean, Variance};

fn main() {
    let m = Mean::new();
    println!("{}", m.mean());
    let mut v = Variance::new();
    println!("{}", v.sample_variance());
    v.add(5.);
    println!("{}", v.sample_variance());
}
```

prints

```
0
0
0
```

However, returning zero for these cases is misleading. I'd suggest returning `f64::NAN`, `None`, or `Err(_)`.

For a data set with 0 elements:

- The sample mean is undefined, since it requires division by 0:

   ```
        n
        ∑ xᵢ
       i=1     0
   x̅ = ――――― = ―
         n     0
   ```

- The sample variance is undefined, since it's defined in terms of deviations from the sample mean, and the sample mean is undefined.

For a data set with 1 element:

- The sample mean is the value of that element:

   ```
        n
        ∑ xᵢ
       i=1     x₁
   x̅ = ――――― = ―― = x₁
         n     1
   ```

- The sample variance is undefined, since it requires division by 0:

   ```
         n
         ∑ (xᵢ−x̅)²
        i=1          (x₁−x₁)²   0
   s² = ―――――――――― = ―――――――― = ―
          n − 1         0       0
   ```

What are your thoughts?

comment.body:
> A branch is necessary only in the implementation of .mean(). Since it doesn't affect the inner loop (the addition of data), the cost should pretty much always be negligible.

I agree. :+1: 

> Would you like me to submit a PR which changes the outputs to NAN?

Sure, that would be very welcome! There will be a bit of churn, because quite a few of the tests have to be adapted.

issue.title: Statistics for data sets with 0 or 1 element
issue.body:
Currently, the following example

```rust
use average::{Estimate, Mean, Variance};

fn main() {
    let m = Mean::new();
    println!("{}", m.mean());
    let mut v = Variance::new();
    println!("{}", v.sample_variance());
    v.add(5.);
    println!("{}", v.sample_variance());
}
```

prints

```
0
0
0
```

However, returning zero for these cases is misleading. I'd suggest returning `f64::NAN`, `None`, or `Err(_)`.

For a data set with 0 elements:

- The sample mean is undefined, since it requires division by 0:

   ```
        n
        ∑ xᵢ
       i=1     0
   x̅ = ――――― = ―
         n     0
   ```

- The sample variance is undefined, since it's defined in terms of deviations from the sample mean, and the sample mean is undefined.

For a data set with 1 element:

- The sample mean is the value of that element:

   ```
        n
        ∑ xᵢ
       i=1     x₁
   x̅ = ――――― = ―― = x₁
         n     1
   ```

- The sample variance is undefined, since it requires division by 0:

   ```
         n
         ∑ (xᵢ−x̅)²
        i=1          (x₁−x₁)²   0
   s² = ―――――――――― = ―――――――― = ―
          n − 1         0       0
   ```

What are your thoughts?

comment.body:
This is intentional (and for the mean documented), but I'm open to return other values than 0. `NAN` seems like the best alternative.

For the mean, returning 0 is convenient, because it avoids having to a add a branch, but the performance difference is probably not important.

In any case, the behavior of the variance for `len < 2` should be documented.

commits.message: update dependencies and bump MSRV

pull_request.title: update dependencies and bump MSRV
pull_request.body:
The current MSRV of 1.36 is increasingly outdated, as are some of the dependencies. This PR updates all dependencies to the latest available versions, and bumps the documented MSRV to 1.51 (which is now ~18 months old):

- serde-big-array 0.4: MSRV 1.51
- proptest 1: MSRV 1.50
- byteorder 1.4.x: MSRV 1.41.1
- bitflags 1.3.x: MSRV 1.46

All linux distributions that I checked should work with Rust 1.51 - except maybe debian stable, which has both Rust 1.48 and 1.51 available.

comment.body:
> But do dev-dependencies even impact MSRV?

At least for Rand they do, because we run the tests with the MSRV. However, [Rand is going to bump the MSRV to 1.51 with the upcoming 0.9 release as well](https://github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1165), so this should be fine to merge.

> The test output looks like a (temporary?) floating point accuracy issue rather than a problem with serde-big-array

Not sure it's temporary, floating-point math is still deterministic. Could also be related to the compiler version, but I think the test was passing before, so what else could it be?

Propagate getrandom errors

issue.title: Replace `fastrand` with `getrandom` and `base64`
issue.body:
- Instead of setting up a predictable userspace RNG, we get unpredictable random bytes directly from the OS. This fixes #178.
- To obtain a uniformly distributed alphanumeric string, we convert the random bytes to base64 and throw away any letters we don't want (`+` and `/`). With a low probability, this may result in obtaining too few alphanumeric letters, in which case we request more randomness from the OS until we have enough.
- Because we cannot control the seed anymore, a test manufacturing collisions by setting the same seed for several threads had to be removed.

comment.body:
> Looking into getrandom, I'm concerned about blocking on early boot (per the getrandom documentation). We'd be trading a potential and unlikely DoS, for a deadlock on some platforms (e.g., an init system built in rust).

Couldn't such a special application generate their own random file name?
This is possible, but the number of retries will no longer be deterministic.

Thanks, this makes sense! Note however that `average` is a dev dependency of Rand, so we need to be careful about raising the MSRV.

There are some issues with the tests:
- The pipeline still needs to be adapted to run Rust 1.51.
- The minimal version of `serde-big-array` might need to be stricter to fix the minimal versions test.

Do we even need `serde-big-array` now that we can use const generics?

issue.body:
- Instead of setting up a predictable userspace RNG, we get unpredictable random bytes directly from the OS. This fixes #178.
- To obtain a uniformly distributed alphanumeric string, we convert the random bytes to base64 and throw away any letters we don't want (`+` and `/`). With a low probability, this may result in obtaining too few alphanumeric letters, in which case we request more randomness from the OS until we have enough.

comment.body:
@Stebalien Would you be ok with a base64 alphabet (e.g. by adding `-` and `_`) to simplify the implementation?

I can get rid of the `base64` dependency, but this would essentially require vendoring a base64 encoder (or using the random bytes inefficiently).

issue.title: Use of predictable RNG
issue.body: This library recently switched to non-CSPRNGs (see #141 and #162), which are inherently predictable based on observations of their output. Doesn't this make the library vulnerable to attacks listed [here](https://owasp.org/www-community/vulnerabilities/Insecure_Temporary_File), because the generated filenames can be predicted?

comment.body:
> Take each byte of input modulo the length of the dictionary and look it up in the dictionary.

Unfortunately, that method is slightly biased and does not result in a uniform alphanumeric distribution.

issue.title: clarify shuffle docs
issue.body:
Fixes https://github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1258

In that issue @vks makes a remark about the generator state space. Is that something that should be mentioned here? I am not sure if I fully understand the remark, it seems to be about fundamental limits of finite-state pseudo-random number generators.

comment.body: Yes, it's about how many different numbers a PRNG with a finite seed / state can generate. It's explained a bit more [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle#Pseudorandom_generators).

issue.title: Is 'shuffle' uniform across all permutations?
issue.body: The documentation for `shuffle` does not explicitly state the probability distribution it implements. What I would expect as a result is a permutation chosen uniformly at random from the set of all permutations. Is that what it does?

comment.body: This also depends on the generator: If the number of permutations is larger than the state can represent, some permutations have zero probability.

issue.title: Statistics for data sets with 0 or 1 element
issue.body:
Currently, the following example

```rust
use average::{Estimate, Mean, Variance};

fn main() {
    let m = Mean::new();
    println!("{}", m.mean());
    let mut v = Variance::new();
    println!("{}", v.sample_variance());
    v.add(5.);
    println!("{}", v.sample_variance());
}
```

prints

```
0
0
0
```

However, returning zero for these cases is misleading. I'd suggest returning `f64::NAN`, `None`, or `Err(_)`.

For a data set with 0 elements:

- The sample mean is undefined, since it requires division by 0:

   ```
        n
        ∑ xᵢ
       i=1     0
   x̅ = ――――― = ―
         n     0
   ```

- The sample variance is undefined, since it's defined in terms of deviations from the sample mean, and the sample mean is undefined.

For a data set with 1 element:

- The sample mean is the value of that element:

   ```
        n
        ∑ xᵢ
       i=1     x₁
   x̅ = ――――― = ―― = x₁
         n     1
   ```

- The sample variance is undefined, since it requires division by 0:

   ```
         n
         ∑ (xᵢ−x̅)²
        i=1          (x₁−x₁)²   0
   s² = ―――――――――― = ―――――――― = ―
          n − 1         0       0
   ```

What are your thoughts?

comment.body:
> A branch is necessary only in the implementation of .mean(). Since it doesn't affect the inner loop (the addition of data), the cost should pretty much always be negligible.

I agree. :+1: 

> Would you like me to submit a PR which changes the outputs to NAN?

Sure, that would be very welcome! There will be a bit of churn, because quite a few of the tests have to be adapted.

issue.title: Statistics for data sets with 0 or 1 element
issue.body:
Currently, the following example

```rust
use average::{Estimate, Mean, Variance};

fn main() {
    let m = Mean::new();
    println!("{}", m.mean());
    let mut v = Variance::new();
    println!("{}", v.sample_variance());
    v.add(5.);
    println!("{}", v.sample_variance());
}
```

prints

```
0
0
0
```

However, returning zero for these cases is misleading. I'd suggest returning `f64::NAN`, `None`, or `Err(_)`.

For a data set with 0 elements:

- The sample mean is undefined, since it requires division by 0:

   ```
        n
        ∑ xᵢ
       i=1     0
   x̅ = ――――― = ―
         n     0
   ```

- The sample variance is undefined, since it's defined in terms of deviations from the sample mean, and the sample mean is undefined.

For a data set with 1 element:

- The sample mean is the value of that element:

   ```
        n
        ∑ xᵢ
       i=1     x₁
   x̅ = ――――― = ―― = x₁
         n     1
   ```

- The sample variance is undefined, since it requires division by 0:

   ```
         n
         ∑ (xᵢ−x̅)²
        i=1          (x₁−x₁)²   0
   s² = ―――――――――― = ―――――――― = ―
          n − 1         0       0
   ```

What are your thoughts?

comment.body:
This is intentional (and for the mean documented), but I'm open to return other values than 0. `NAN` seems like the best alternative.

For the mean, returning 0 is convenient, because it avoids having to a add a branch, but the performance difference is probably not important.

In any case, the behavior of the variance for `len < 2` should be documented.

pull_request.title: update dependencies and bump MSRV
pull_request.body:
The current MSRV of 1.36 is increasingly outdated, as are some of the dependencies. This PR updates all dependencies to the latest available versions, and bumps the documented MSRV to 1.51 (which is now ~18 months old):

- serde-big-array 0.4: MSRV 1.51
- proptest 1: MSRV 1.50
- byteorder 1.4.x: MSRV 1.41.1
- bitflags 1.3.x: MSRV 1.46

All linux distributions that I checked should work with Rust 1.51 - except maybe debian stable, which has both Rust 1.48 and 1.51 available.

comment.body:
> But do dev-dependencies even impact MSRV?

At least for Rand they do, because we run the tests with the MSRV. However, [Rand is going to bump the MSRV to 1.51 with the upcoming 0.9 release as well](https://github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1165), so this should be fine to merge.

> The test output looks like a (temporary?) floating point accuracy issue rather than a problem with serde-big-array

Not sure it's temporary, floating-point math is still deterministic. Could also be related to the compiler version, but I think the test was passing before, so what else could it be?

issue.title: Replace `fastrand` with `getrandom` and `base64`
issue.body:
- Instead of setting up a predictable userspace RNG, we get unpredictable random bytes directly from the OS. This fixes #178.
- To obtain a uniformly distributed alphanumeric string, we convert the random bytes to base64 and throw away any letters we don't want (`+` and `/`). With a low probability, this may result in obtaining too few alphanumeric letters, in which case we request more randomness from the OS until we have enough.
- Because we cannot control the seed anymore, a test manufacturing collisions by setting the same seed for several threads had to be removed.

comment.body:
> Looking into getrandom, I'm concerned about blocking on early boot (per the getrandom documentation). We'd be trading a potential and unlikely DoS, for a deadlock on some platforms (e.g., an init system built in rust).

Couldn't such a special application generate their own random file name?
This is possible, but the number of retries will no longer be deterministic.

- Instead of setting up a predictable userspace RNG, we get unpredictable random bytes directly from the OS. This fixes #178.
- To obtain a uniformly distributed alphanumeric string, we convert the random bytes to base64 and throw away any letters we don't want (`+` and `/`). comment.body:
@Stebalien Would you be ok with a base64 alphabet (e.g. by adding `-` and `_`) to simplify the implementation?

I can get rid of the `base64` dependency, but this would essentially require vendoring a base64 encoder (or using the random bytes inefficiently).

issue.title: Use of predictable RNG
issue.body: This library recently switched to non-CSPRNGs (see #141 and #162), which are inherently predictable based on observations of their output. Doesn't this make the library vulnerable to attacks listed [here](https://owasp.org/www-community/vulnerabilities/Insecure_Temporary_File), because the generated filenames can be predicted?

comment.body:
> Take each byte of input modulo the length of the dictionary and look it up in the dictionary.

Unfortunately, that method is slightly biased and does not result in a uniform alphanumeric distribution.

issue.title: clarify shuffle docs
issue.body:
Fixes https://github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1258

In that issue @vks makes a remark about the generator state space. Is that something that should be mentioned here? I am not sure if I fully understand the remark, it seems to be about fundamental limits of finite-state pseudo-random number generators.

comment.body: Yes, it's about how many different numbers a PRNG with a finite seed / state can generate. It's explained a bit more [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle#Pseudorandom_generators).

issue.title: Is 'shuffle' uniform across all permutations?
issue.body: The documentation for `shuffle` does not explicitly state the probability distribution it implements. What I would expect as a result is a permutation chosen uniformly at random from the set of all permutations. Is that what it does?

comment.body: This also depends on the generator: If the number of permutations is larger than the state can represent, some permutations have zero probability.

issue.title: Statistics for data sets with 0 or 1 element
issue.body:
Currently, the following example

```rust
use average::{Estimate, Mean, Variance};

fn main() {
    let m = Mean::new();
    println!("{}", m.mean());
    let mut v = Variance::new();
    println!("{}", v.sample_variance());
    v.add(5.);
    println!("{}", v.sample_variance());
}
```

prints

```
0
0
0
```

However, returning zero for these cases is misleading. I'd suggest returning `f64::NAN`, `None`, or `Err(_)`.

For a data set with 0 elements:

- The sample mean is undefined, since it requires division by 0:

   ```
        n
        ∑ xᵢ
       i=1     0
   x̅ = ――――― = ―
         n     0
   ```

- The sample variance is undefined, since it's defined in terms of deviations from the sample mean, and the sample mean is undefined.

For a data set with 1 element:

- The sample mean is the value of that element:

   ```
        n
        ∑ xᵢ
       i=1     x₁
   x̅ = ――――― = ―― = x₁
         n     1
   ```

- The sample variance is undefined, since it requires division by 0:

   ```
         n
         ∑ (xᵢ−x̅)²
        i=1          (x₁−x₁)²   0
   s² = ―――――――――― = ―――――――― = ―
          n − 1         0       0
   ```

What are your thoughts?

comment.body:
> A branch is necessary only in the implementation of .mean(). Since it doesn't affect the inner loop (the addition of data), the cost should pretty much always be negligible.

I agree. :+1: 

> Would you like me to submit a PR which changes the outputs to NAN?

Sure, that would be very welcome! There will be a bit of churn, because quite a few of the tests have to be adapted.

issue.title: Statistics for data sets with 0 or 1 element
issue.body:
Currently, the following example

```rust
use average::{Estimate, Mean, Variance};

fn main() {
    let m = Mean::new();
    println!("{}", m.mean());
    let mut v = Variance::new();
    println!("{}", v.sample_variance());
    v.add(5.);
    println!("{}", v.sample_variance());
}
```

prints

```
0
0
0
```

However, returning zero for these cases is misleading. I'd suggest returning `f64::NAN`, `None`, or `Err(_)`.

For a data set with 0 elements:

- The sample mean is undefined, since it requires division by 0:

   ```
        n
        ∑ xᵢ
       i=1     0
   x̅ = ――――― = ―
         n     0
   ```

- The sample variance is undefined, since it's defined in terms of deviations from the sample mean, and the sample mean is undefined.

For a data set with 1 element:

- The sample mean is the value of that element:

   ```
        n
        ∑ xᵢ
       i=1     x₁
   x̅ = ――――― = ―― = x₁
         n     1
   ```

- The sample variance is undefined, since it requires division by 0:

   ```
         n
         ∑ (xᵢ−x̅)²
        i=1          (x₁−x₁)²   0
   s² = ―――――――――― = ―――――――― = ―
          n − 1         0       0
   ```

What are your thoughts?

comment.body:
This is intentional (and for the mean documented), but I'm open to return other values than 0. `NAN` seems like the best alternative.

For the mean, returning 0 is convenient, because it avoids having to a add a branch, but the performance difference is probably not important.

In any case, the behavior of the variance for `len < 2` should be documented.

pull_request.title: update dependencies and bump MSRV
pull_request.body:
The current MSRV of 1.36 is increasingly outdated, as are some of the dependencies. This PR updates all dependencies to the latest available versions, and bumps the documented MSRV to 1.51 (which is now ~18 months old):

- serde-big-array 0.4: MSRV 1.51
- proptest 1: MSRV 1.50
- byteorder 1.4.x: MSRV 1.41.1
- bitflags 1.3.x: MSRV 1.46

All linux distributions that I checked should work with Rust 1.51 - except maybe debian stable, which has both Rust 1.48 and 1.51 available.

comment.body:
> But do dev-dependencies even impact MSRV?

At least for Rand they do, because we run the tests with the MSRV. However, [Rand is going to bump the MSRV to 1.51 with the upcoming 0.9 release as well](https://github.com/rust-random/rand/issues/1165), so this should be fine to merge.

> The test output looks like a (temporary?) floating point accuracy issue rather than a problem with serde-big-array

Not sure it's temporary, floating-point math is still deterministic. Could also be related to the compiler version, but I think the test was passing before, so what else could it be?

issue.title: Replace `fastrand` with `getrandom` and `base64`
issue.body:
- Instead of setting up a predictable userspace RNG, we get unpredictable random bytes directly from the OS. This fixes #178.
- To obtain a uniformly distributed alphanumeric string, we convert the random bytes to base64 and throw away any letters we don't want (`+` and `/`). With a low probability, this may result in obtaining too few alphanumeric letters, in which case we request more randomness from the OS until we have enough.
- Because we cannot control the seed anymore, a test manufacturing collisions by setting the same seed for several threads had to be removed.

comment.body:
> Looking into getrandom, I'm concerned about blocking on early boot (per the getrandom documentation). We'd be trading a potential and unlikely DoS, for a deadlock on some platforms (e.g., an init system built in rust).

Couldn't such a special application generate their own random file name?
This is possible, but the number of retries will no longer be deterministic.

issue.title: Use of predictable RNG
issue.body: This library recently switched to non-CSPRNGs (see #141 and #162), which are inherently predictable based on observations of their output. Doesn't this make the library vulnerable to attacks listed [here](https://owasp.org/www-community/vulnerabilities/Insecure_Temporary_File), because the generated filenames can be predicted?

comment.body:
> Take each byte of input modulo the length of the dictionary and look it up in the dictionary.

Unfortunately, that method is slightly biased and does not result in a uniform alphanumeric distribution.
